index.headline1: MMDA: An interactive toolkit for Corpus-based Discourse Analysis
index.paragraph1: Corpus-based Discourse Analysis (CDA) is a popular and highly successful technique for the investigation of socio-political research questions.  The CDA procedure starts from a collocation analysis for a given node (oftentimes representing a topic of interest).  The collocates are then grouped into semantically meaningful categories (e.g. attitudes and opinions) based on careful inspection of the corresponding KWIC concordances.
index.paragraph2: The web application you are using here – the interactive Mixed Methods Discourse Analysis (MMDA) toolkit – is a bespoke software solution that combines the necessary steps of CDA into a single consistent and efficient working environment. The most labour-intensive task of CDA, the manual grouping of lexical items into discoursemes, can be carried out interactively via drag & drop.
index.paragraph3: From a Digital Humanities perspective, the toolkit can be understood as an attempt to blend close and distant reading techniques.  On the one hand, the app provides you with an intuitive visualization of collocation profiles in form of a semantic map.   On the other hand, easily accessible and exportable concordance lines accompany all summarizations.
index.paragraph4: See the Vignette for further info or click on New Discourseme.
index.Acknowledgements: This work was supported by the Emerging Fields Initiative (EFI) of Friedrich-Alexander-Universität Erlangen-Nürnberg, project title Exploring the 'Fukushima Effect' (EFE).

about.headline: Vignette
about.paragraph1_1: The MMDA toolkit can be used in a specialized way to (1) query corpora using the Corpus Query Processor (CQP) of the IMS Open Corpus Workbench (CWB), (2) to visualize collocation lists via semantic maps, (3) to create and store discoursemes in a consistent database, and (4) to analyse discourseme constellations.  In principle, any corpus indexed with the CWB can be imported in the toolkit.  For all visualzations, word embeddings of the respective token-layer (for the given language and register) must be at hand.
about.paragraph1_2: A typical starting point of CDA is a 'topic query': a set of words and multi-word units on any positional annotation layer of the corpus. The available layers depend on the actual linguistic annotation of the corpus at hand, but for most corpora the three layers 'word' and 'lemma' should be present. A typical topic query is made up of semantically related topic nodes such as {'erneuerbare Energie', 'Windenergie', 'Solarenergie', 'Wasserkraft'}, which aims to capture a specific topic you are interested in. For a topic in the sense of CDA, it is reasonable to query on the lemma layer, i.e. to choose 'p-att: lemma' in the 'New Analysis' pane.
about.paragraph1_3: The 'window size' and 's-break' parameters determine the windows around the retrieved topic nodes that will be highlighted in concordance views and which will be used to determine the domain of collocate candidates. For most texts, sentences should be used as break points ('s-break: s'). Newspaper texts might also contain 'article' or 'p' (for paragraph); CMC data might contain 'tweet' or 'post'. The most generic s-break value is 'text'. Typical values for the window size are 3 to 10, although some researchers might be interested in values as low as 1 (essentially looking for trigrams), others in window sizes of 10 and above, looking for patterns across lexical items far away from one another.
about.paragraph1_4: Every analysis – consisting of topic query, s-att, p-att, and corpus – has to be named for further identification. This way, topic queries (and their related analyses) can be used within later analyses.
about.paragraph2_1: The immediate result of the analysis is a summarization of the cotext (the textual context defined by window size and s-break) of the topic nodes: You can see (1)  the 'frequency breakdown' of the topic query. (2) The 'collocation' segment presents the collocate candidates of the topic nodes for different association measures subject to window size. (3) The 'concordance' segment shows concordance lines of the topic query.
about.paragraph2_2: Additionally, a semantic cloud of the lexical items in the collocation list can be displayed. The initial cloud is a straightforward visualization of the collocation table: It uses a stochastic dimensionality reduction algorithm to place the lexical items in a semantically structured two-dimensional plane (especially trying to place semantically similar items next to one another). The size of the lexical items represent the association of the item with the topic query; the collocation parameters can be used for changing the appearance of the semantic cloud.
about.paragraph2_3: Clicking on items in the semantic cloud retrieves concordances for co-occurrences of the respective item and the topic query.
about.paragraph3_1: A discourseme is a user-created selection of related lexical items. On its surface, it represents a simple list of lexical items, which the researcher decided belong together. The list of topic nodes form a special discourseme – the topic discourseme.
about.paragraph3_2: The semantic cloud is interactive, meaning that lexical items can be grouped together via drag & drop to form additional discoursemes. The cloud can also display second-order collocates of a selected discourseme in the same semantic cloud, i.e. lexical items that are highly associated with the co-occurrence of the topic discourseme and the selected discourseme.
about.paragraph4_1: The easiest discourseme constellation that can be formed consists of a topic discourseme and one further a group of collocates. Such a constellation prototypically consists of the topic (realized by the topic discourseme) and a certain attitude that can be taken towards that topic (realized by the second discourseme).

new.name: discourseme
new.helpName: either select a discourseme or enter a name for a new discourseme
new.helpItems: uni- or n-gram queries forming the node of the collocation analysis (e.g. 'powerplant', 'nuclear energy')
new.helpPQuery: positional attribute to query (e.g. word, lemma)
new.helpSBreak: structural attribute for breaking the context (e.g. sentence (s), paragraph (p), tweet).
new.helpWindowSize: maximum number of tokens to look left and right of the matches
new.no_collocates: No collocates of the given item(s) were found in the given corpus.
new.no_topic: None of the items have been found in the given corpus.

concordances.not_found: No such analysis or no concordance available.

collocates.not_found: No such analysis or no collocates available.

new.name: name
new.helpText: A discourseme is a user-created list of lexical items, e.g. a list of near-synonymous lemmas.
new.helpName: User-defined name for the new discourseme
new.helpItems: Set of lemmas or multi-lemma units.

new.name: Constellation Name
new.helpText: A constellation is a the co-occurrence of several discoursemes, e.g. a certain attitude towards a topic.
new.helpDiscoursemes: A selection of the available discoursemes that are included in the constellation.

extraction.helpText: The concordances extraction is based on the previously associated discoursemes, a selection of corpora and a set of topic items (from an analysis).
extraction.helpCorpora: Selection of corpora to extract (random) concordances from.
extraction.helpAnalysis: The topic discourseme items of this analysis will be used for the concordance extraction.
